results.title: Backbone of the club
results.brief_description:
They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club
A film by Malcolm McKinnon
Football Stories from Country Victoria, An initiative of the Victorian Country Football League and the State Library of Victoria, 2007

Contributors

Terms of use

Malcolm McKinnon, 2006.

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club
A film by Malcolm McKinnon
Football Stories from Country Victoria, An initiative of the Victorian Country Football League and the State Library of Victoria, 2007

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

JAN ENDERS: I’ve had three sons play over the years. And I get on well with the ladies, so I’ll turn up and help. We never miss the footy. We like away games because we can watch. Home games, I have most to do with the lolly stall and keeping the drinks in the fridge and backing up in the kitchen. We sometimes see the last quarter. Don’t see much else.

[SEWING MACHINE WHIRRING]

I do all the sewing, and if there’s any repairs, I take them home, bring them back Saturday morning. Our thirds and reserves won last year, and we’ve always let them have their jumpers. So you order your jumpers very early and you don’t know what players you’re going to have in sizes. So I’ve probably sewed on 100 numbers prior to the start of the season.

ROE HARRAP: I started off going with a guy who played here, ended up marrying him, and now my children are playing here. So yeah, it really is a family affair.

[LAUGHTER]

Women are at backbone s of the football club here. I believe that women play a huge role in country football. And particularly here, if he didn’t have the women behind the club, they wouldn’t be where they are now.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: Oh, I love the club, and I love all the people. We’re all good friends. Actually, last week we were very short in the seconds. I got named as an emergency on the bench.

[LAUGHTER]

But this way, I think I got more players back. I said, well, just get me some boots and I’ll be right.

results.title: In Conversation with Tully Arnot
results.brief_description: In conversation with artist Tully Arnot and ACMI curator Shelley McSpedden to discuss the development of his new work Epiphytes as the Mordant Family VR Commission’s recipient.

production_dates.notes: Live streamed online In Conversation conducted through ACMI's You Tube channel

results.title: Mary's Story
results.creator_credit: Mary Herbert and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
Mary tells of her personal experience living with cerebral palsy. She recounts being told she could never walk, but her parents, determined that she could, helped her achieve this milestone. Mary goes on to speak about the troubles she has faced later in life.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Quilts of Understanding
results.creator_credit: Jenene Egan and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
In this story, Jenene tells of her life-long passion for all things craft. Recounting one of her proudest moments, she speaks about some patches that she created for a collaborative quilt-making project, which was exhibited at her Uniting Church and throughout regional Victoria.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Generations of Hands
results.creator_credit: Jennette Moore and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
Jennette was born in Ballarat. In this digital story, she talks about her personal experience growing up as a deaf person. She recalls learning how to sign and memories with her little brother and parents. Jennette also tells of her children (one of whom was sadly still-born) and grandchildren.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: The Next Chapter
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Craig Dawson
results.brief_description:
Craig Dawson shares his personal experience of being diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis, a disease that his grandmother also suffered from. Craig dedicates this story to her.

This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: The Sound of a Meringue Being Tortured
results.creator_credit: Antony Riddell and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. A stop-motion animated short film where the characters repeatedly ask ‘Are you alright, mate?’.

results.title: Hopes and Dreams
results.creator_credit: Alex Litsoudis and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. Alex tells of a horrifying abuse he suffered in his childhood that resulted in permanent effects on his life. Following his passion for drama, Alex co-founded the ‘Ability Bunch’.

results.title: My Dad
results.creator_credit: Marita Castelino and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. Marita recounts memories of her father.

results.title: Visit to the Tulip Farm
results.creator_credit: John Barnett and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. John recounts the highlights of visiting a tulip farm in Silvan and other places.
